s2.title: Running SAXWriter and DOMWriter
s2.p: SAXWriter and DOMWriter parse your input file, and print it out in XML format. A command line option can be used to print in a "canonical" XML format so the output can be used to compare XML documents. SAXWriter and DOMWriter also display any errors or warnings that occurred during the parse.
SAXWriter uses either the validating or non-validating SAX parser. DOMWriter uses either the validating or non-validating DOM parser.
DOMWriter provides a -e switch to set the output Java encoding.
The command lines below expect the current directory to be the directory containing the JAR file.

ul.li: JDK is loaded on your computer.

s2.title: SAXWriter

ol.li: open up a MS-DOS command line window
set the path to the jdk\bin directory
change directory to the latest &javaparserdirectory; directory

s2.p: The easiest way to do this is to create a .bat file using the Notepad editor. Then the SAXWriter can be invoked by double clicking on the file name or icon. The following command lines assume that both the jdk and the &javaparserdirectory; directories are located directly below the c: drive.
s2.source: set path=c:\jdk1.1.8\bin;%PATH% set classpath=c:\&javaparserdirectory;\&javaparserdirectory;.jar;%CLASSPATH% set classpath=c:\&javaparserdirectory;\&javaparserdirectory;Samples;%CLASSPATH% cd c:\&javaparserdirectory; java sax.SAXWriter data\personal.xml
s2.p: SAXCount also allows you to change the default behavior using the following command line flags:

ul.li:
-p Specify the parser class to be used.
The available parsers are:
-h Print SAXWriter help information. [default is no help]
-c Output in canonical format. [default is normal format]

s2.title: DOMWriter

ol.li: open up a MS-DOS command line window
set the path to the jdk\bin directory
change directory to the latest &javaparserdirectory; directory

s2.p: The easiest way to do this is to create a .bat file using the Notepad editor. Then the DOMWriter can be invoked by double clicking on the file name or icon. The following command lines assume that both the jdk and the &javaparserdirectory; directories are located directly below the c: dirve.
s2.source: set path=c:\jdk1.1.8\bin;%PATH% set classpath=c:\&javaparserdirectory;\&javaparserdirectory;.jar;%CLASSPATH% set classpath=c:\&javaparserdirectory;\&javaparserdirectory;Samples;%CLASSPATH% cd c:\&javaparserdirectory; java dom.DOMWriter data\personal.xml
s2.p: DOMCount also allows you to change the default behavior via the following command line flags (type this in as one long command line):

ul.li:
-p Specify the parser class to be used.
The available parsers are:
-h Print DOMWriter help information. [default is no help]
-c Output in canonical format. [default is normal format]
-e encodingName Output using the specified encoding. [default is UTF8]
